summary: This is a series of forwarded emails from September 2019 between FBI and DOJ officials discussing potential compensation for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The emails inquire about whether victims can apply for compensation through the Office of Victim Services (OVS) and mention the need for a letter from a prosecutor. The correspondence expresses frustration about recent events.

events.title: Inquiry about Epstein victim compensation
events.description: An FBI official emails the Office of Victim Services (OVS) to ask if victims of Jeffrey Epstein can still apply for compensation even though they disclosed the abuse years after it occurred.

events.title: FBI forwards victim compensation request to SDNY
events.description: FBI officials forward a request regarding victim compensation for Epstein victims to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) for action.

keyFacts: FBI officials were actively working with multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein in the New York City area in 2019.

The Office of Victim Services (OVS) indicated that victim compensation could be possible if a letter from a District Attorney or Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) was provided, confirming they would have prosecuted if the case had been brought in a timely manner.
The Executive Director of OVS expressed being 'so angry about what happened over the weekend,' likely referencing events related to Epstein's death or case developments in August 2019.
The email chain shows coordination between the FBI's Victim Services Division and federal prosecutors (SDNY) regarding victim support.
The document highlights the ongoing effort to secure financial compensation for Epstein's victims years after the abuse occurred.
